0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11K2QK	Nearly half of Americans ‘very concerned’ about Clinton emails: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Nearly half of American adults are ""very concerned"" about two issues that have hounded Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign this year: her use of a private email server to conduct government business and donations to her family's charitable foundation
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Wednesday. Both issues stem from Clinton's tenure between 2009 and 2013 as secretary of state
column3: during President Barack Obama's first term. During that time
column4: she used an unauthorized private email server to conduct government business - something that the Federal Bureau of Investigation earlier this summer criticized as ""extremely careless."" The Clinton Foundation's acceptance of donations from foreign governments and corporations while Clinton herself was secretary of state has drawn criticism about possible conflicts of interest. In August
column5: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump called on the Justice Department to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate whether Clinton granted any special favors in exchange for those donations.The Sept. 2-11 online poll found that 46 percent of American adults said they were ""very concerned"" about Clinton's use of a personal email account
column6: while 47 percent said the same about donations from foreign governments or corporations to the Clinton Foundation.The public appears to have mostly responded to these issues along party lines
column7: with nearly twice as many Republicans expressing concern as Democrats. However
column8: a considerable portion of Democrats appear to be just as rattled by the reports.

column1: Among Democrats
column2: 21 percent were very concerned about Clinton's emails
column3: and 22 percent were very concerned about the Clinton Foundation donations. Among Clinton supporters
column4: 14 percent said they are very concerned about the emails
column5: and the same proportion said they are concerned about donations.The issues
column6: which have drawn wide attention by the media and by her opponents
column8: but it is not clear whether they have made a lasting impact on her level of support in the presidential race against Trump
column9: where she holds a small lead.

column1: Since the beginning of August
column2: a growing portion of Americans have expressed a negative view of Clinton. Yet
column3: when asked to pick between her and Trump for president
column4: Americans have given a small
column5: but consistent advantage to Clinton.According to the poll
column6: among the respondents who said they were concerned about the emails
column7: 52 percent said the main reason was because the emails might contain classified information that was vulnerable to hackers. Another 40 percent were mostly concerned that Clinton had violated State Department policies. Among those who said they were concerned about donations to the Clinton Foundation
column8: 48 percent said they were generally concerned about foreign money being contributed to organizations run by high-ranking politicians
column9: while 38 percent said they were specifically concerned that donors had more access to Clinton while she was serving in the Obama administration.

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states. It asked questions only to those respondents who were aware of the email and the Clinton Foundation issues. There were 2
column2: 745 respondents for the email questions
column3: including 1
column4: 070 registered Democrats and 944 registered Republicans. There were  2
column5: 116 respondents for the Foundation questions
column6: including 817 registered Democrats and 801 registered Republicans. The poll has a credibility interval
column8: of 2 percentage points for the entire sample
column9: and 4 points for the Democrats and Republicans. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-music-mana-idUSKCN11K27Q	Mexican band Maná urges Latinos to vote in U.S. election	"
Members of Mana
column2: the Spanish-language pop band
column3: are embarking on what they hope will be their most influential series of performances - the U.S. ""Latino Power Tour"" - seeking to encourage Latinos to use their power at the polls in the Nov. 8 presidential election.""We are so proud
column4: on one hand 'Latino Power Tour
column5: ' it's a celebration
column6: but we're also suggesting for Latinos to use their power with their vote. They can change history in this country
column7: said vocalist Fher Olvera.The tour opened in San Diego on Sept. 9 and is scheduled to end in Los Angeles on Nov. 13. The band
column8: sometimes referred to  as ""the U2 of Spanish rock
column9: will perform in 18 major arenas across the United States.The band from Guadalajara
column11: has always been vocal about denouncing violence and corruption in its home country. Now
column12: in the wake of some unfavorable comments about Mexicans by Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump - who has also threatened to expel millions of Mexicans - Mana feels its influence can make a difference in the United States as well.

column1: Latinos can move the scale of history in the United States
column2: they can rewrite history and I believe they deserve a lot more than what has been given to them
column3: and they have the power
column4: Olvera said in an interview.For the ""Latino Power Tour
column5: Mana will perform a career-spanning set including greatest hits and songs from its ninth studio album
column6: ""Cama Incendiada"" (Bed on Fire). It has also partnered with organizations including Voto Latino and local advocates to provide both inspiration and information Latinos might need to make their voices heard in the upcoming election.

column1: More than anything
column2: it's a huge celebration of the Latino community
column3: said drummer Alex Gonzalez. ""You know
column4: the Latino community has given so much and has worked so hard here in the United States
column5: developed the country
column6: especially economically. On the other hand also
column7: this tour is to emphasize Latinos to go out and vote."" Mana has earned four Grammy Awards
column8: eight Latin Grammy Awards and sold more than 40 million albums.

column1: (Reporting by Reuters TV; Writing by Melissa Fares; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-foundation-idUSKCN11K2EK	Clinton Foundation plans to spin off flagship health project	"
By Jonathan Allen
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The Bill
column2: Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation would spin off its flagship health project into a ""completely independent"" charity if Hillary Clinton were to win the U.S. presidency in November
column3: the charity announced on Wednesday.The Clinton Health Access Initiative
column4: which has focused on reducing the cost of HIV medicine in sub-Saharan Africa
column5: currently accounts for about two thirds of the foundation's annual income and expenses
column6: according to disclosures online. The promise to carve it out of the foundation aims to quash concerns that donors might try to seek special access in a Clinton White House. Bill and Chelsea Clinton
column8: would step down from the health project's board and the project would no longer use the Clinton name and instead would go by its acronym
column10: if the family returned to the White House next year
column11: the announcement said.Clinton has defended her family's philanthropic organizations against accusations by Donald Trump
column15: might expect favorable treatment from the U.S. government. She has said no donor ever received inappropriate favors
column16: but her staff have said she recognizes reorganization would be necessary to avoid any appearance of conflicts of interests.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: New York State Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said his office had opened an inquiry into the Donald J. Trump Foundation to ensure the Republican presidential nominee's charity was complying with state laws governing nonprofits.The inquiry followed reports by The Washington Post regarding Trump's Foundation and his contributions to the charity. He has refused to release his tax returns
column3: which would show charitable giving.

column1: Long-time Clinton associates Bruce Lindsey
column2: Ira Magaziner and Maggie Williams would also step down from CHAI's board
column3: and the remaining board members would replace all five in consultation with global health experts
column4: the charity said. Magaziner
column5: who has been friends with Bill Clinton since they were students at Oxford University
column6: would remain as the project's chief executive. The board would draft a ""succession plan"" by the end of the year
column7: the announcement said.""If Secretary Clinton is elected president
column8: the changes outlined here will be implemented and CHAI would become an organization completely independent of the Clinton Foundation

column1: Bill Clinton set up the foundation as he prepared to leave the White House in 2001. Hillary Clinton joined its board after  leaving the U.S. State Department in 2013 but stepped down last year to seek the presidency. The foundation announced last month that it would no longer accept donations from foreigners or corporations for its other work besides CHAI
column2: and said it would close overseas fundraising arms in Sweden and the United Kingdom. (Reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Chris Reese and Andrew Hay)"

WASHINGTON President Barack Obama said on Wednesday that a new $38 billion aid package will help ensure Israel can defend itself from threats
column2: commenting in a statement on the 10-year memorandum of understanding (MOU) between the two nations.""Both Prime Minister (Benjamin) Netanyahu and I are confident that the new MOU will make a significant contribution to Israel's security in what remains a dangerous neighborhood

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-democrats-idUSKCN11K02T	U.S. Democratic Party says more documents leaked
column2: blames Russians	"

column1: (This 13th September story was refiled to correct the headline and first paragraph to make clear more documents released from earlier breach
column2: not a new hack)WASHINGTON The head of the Democratic National Committee said on Tuesday the organization had been hacked by Russian state-sponsored agents who were trying to influence the U.S. presidential election and they may have released more documents after a similar leak in July roiled the party.A link to the documents was posted on WikiLeaks' Twitter account and attributed to alleged hacker Guccifer 2.0. The release came during a presentation on Tuesday from a person speaking on behalf of Guccifer 2.0 at a London cyber security conference
column3: Politico reported.Reuters could not immediately access the documents. ""There's one person who stands to benefit from these criminal acts
column4: and that's (Republican presidential nominee) Donald Trump
column5: DNC interim Chair Donna Brazile said in a statement.

column1: Not only has Trump embraced (Russian President Vladimir)Putin
column2: he publicly encouraged further Russian espionage to help his campaign
column3: she said.Trump in July invited Russia to dig up emails from Clinton's time as secretary of state
column4: prompting Democrats to accuse him of urging foreigners to spy on Americans. He later said he was speaking sarcastically.The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigned as DNC chair on the eve of July's Democratic National Convention after WikiLeaks published an earlier trove of hacked DNC emails that showed party officials favoring eventual nominee Hillary Clinton over U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders during the party's nominating contests. Three other senior officials also stepped down from the DNC after the leak.""We have been anticipating that an additional batch of documents stolen by Russian agents would be released
column2: said Brazile
column3: who took over from Wasserman Schultz on an interim basis.

column1: Democratic Party sources said the party and Clinton's presidential campaign were deeply concerned about possible publication by WikiLeaks or other hackers of a new torrent of potentially embarrassing party information ahead of the Nov. 8 election. (Reporting by Eric Beech and Mark Hosenball; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-investigation-idUSKCN11J2SY	New York attorney general opens probe of Trump Foundation	"

New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said on Tuesday he had opened an inquiry into the Donald J. Trump Foundation to ensure the Republican presidential nominee's charity was complying with state laws governing nonprofits.Schneiderman
column2: a supporter of Trump's Democratic rival in the presidential race
column3: Hillary Clinton
column4: sued the real estate mogul and his now defunct Trump University for fraud in 2013
column5: seeking $40 million in restitution plus penalties and other costs.In a CNN interview on Tuesday
column6: Schneiderman said his office had now brought Trump's charitable foundation under scrutiny.""My interest in this issue really is in my capacity as regulator of nonprofits in New York state. And we have been concerned that the Trump Foundation may have engaged in some impropriety from that point of view
column7: the elected Democratic official said.He added: ""We have been looking into the Trump Foundation to make sure it's complying with the laws that govern charities in New York."" He did not elaborate on what wrongdoing Trump's nonprofit might have committed.Trump campaign spokesman Steven Cheung dismissed Schneiderman's assertions as entirely motivated by presidential politics
column8: calling the attorney general a ""partisan hack who has turned a blind eye to the Clinton Foundation for years.""

column1: Cheung called Schneiderman's comments ""nothing more than another left-wing hit job designed to distract"" attention from Clinton's recent missteps on the campaign trail.Trump has accused Clinton of being corrupted by donors to the Clinton Foundation global charity founded by her husband
column2: former President Bill Clinton
column3: while she was U.S. secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.

column1: Clinton has dismissed Trump's allegation as a political smear. There has been no evidence that foreign donors to the foundation obtained favors from the State Department while Clinton headed the agency.Schneiderman made his remarks when asked on CNN about calls from Democrats in Congress for a federal investigation of a $25
column2: 000 donation in 2013 from the Trump Foundation to a political committee supporting Florida's Republican attorney general
column3: Pam Bondi. Democrats have cited an Associated Press report that Bondi solicited the donation personally
column4: around the time her office was debating whether to join New York state's investigation into Trump's real estate training school in Florida. According to the AP
column5: Bondi
column6: who was seeking re-election at the time
column7: broke off the lawsuit deliberations after the check arrived.

column1: Bondi
column2: who has endorsed Trump
column3: has called the AP report misleading. (Additional reporting by Mohammad Zargham in Washington)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-mylan-nl-epipen-congress-idUSKCN11K1OP	Mylan CEO to testify before House panel over EpiPen pricing	"
WASHINGTON Mylan NL Chief Executive Officer Heather Bresch will appear at a Sept. 21 congressional hearing over price increases for its EpiPen emergency allergy treatment
column2: the U.S. House of Representatives Oversight Committee said in a statement on Wednesday.Mylan has been widely criticized
column3: including by U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column4: for sharply raising the price of EpiPens
column5: which are carried by people with life-threatening allergies.Mylan
column6: which acquired the product in 2007
column7: recently raised the list price for a pair of EpiPen auto-injectors to $600. The price has been rising from a cost of about $100 in 2008. Mylan spokeswoman Nina Devlin confirmed that Bresch will attend the hearing.""Heather is very good at being able to give an answer without offering much information
column8: said Evercore ISI analyst Umer Raffat
column9: adding that he will be watching for any other issues that might be raised by the Committee. A probe into EpiPen pricing by a U.S. Senate subcommittee was announced on Sept. 7.

column1: Bresch is the daughter of U.S. Senator Joe Manchin
column2: a Democrat from West Virginia.The House panel co-chairmen
column3: Republican Representative Jason Chaffetz and Democratic Representative Elijah Cummings
column4: noted there is ""... justified outrage from families and schools across the country struggling to afford the high cost of EpiPens.""

column1: The committee planned to look at how to spur competition in the EpiPen market and speed approval by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of generic alternatives
column2: according to the statement.In response to the furor
column3: Mylan last month said it would sell its own generic version of EpiPen for $300.Teva Pharmaceutical Industries
column4: which for years has been working on developing a generic alternative to EpiPen
column5: said last week that it hopes to gain U.S. approval by late 2017 or early 20018.

column1: EpiPen
column2: which has annual sales of about $1 billion
column3: delivers a potentially life-saving dose of epinephrine by injection into the thigh to counter dangerous allergic reactions
column4: including to peanuts and bee stings. Mylan owns 94 percent of the market for such auto-injected devices.The committee said it also planned to call as a witness Dr Doug Throckmorton
column5: the FDA's deputy director at the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research.     (Reporting by Eric Walsh and Susan Heavey in Washington and Bill Berkrot in New York; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama
column6: Bernard Orr)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKCN11K26F	Blocking Internet oversight transition a 'gift to Russia': Obama administration	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Delaying or blocking a planned transition of oversight of the Internet's technical management from the U.S. to a global community of stakeholders would be a ""gift to Russia"" and other authoritarian regimes
column2: a senior Obama administration official said Wednesday.The comments before a congressional panel came as several Republican lawmakers are attempting to thwart the changeover
column3: due to occur on Oct. 1
column4: arguing it would stifle online freedom and has not been appropriately vetted.    ""I urge you: Do not give a gift to Russia and other authoritarian nations by blocking this transition
column5: Lawrence Strickling
column6: administrator of the U.S. Commerce Department's National Telecommunications and Information Administration
column9: to transfer oversight of the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers
column11: is expected to go forward unless Congress votes to block the handover. The California-based corporation operates the database for domain names such as .com and .net and their corresponding numeric addresses that allow computers to connect.

column1: The U.S. Commerce Department currently oversees the Internet's management largely because it was invented in the United States. Its contract with ICANN will lapse on October 1.Senator John Thune
column2: a senior Republican from South Dakota
column3: told reporters Tuesday he expected lawmakers would add language to delay the Internet transition to a bill to fund the government past the end of September.Strickling's testimony were an attempt to rebut concerns raised by Republican Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column4: who convened and chaired Wednesday's hearing on the Internet
column5: and other Republicans who have argued in recent weeks that the transition would be a ""giveaway"" of Internet control to Russia
column6: China
column7: and other governments that censor Internet content.

column1: When ICANN escapes from government authority
column2: ICANN escapes from ... having to worry about protecting your rights or my rights
column3: Cruz said.ICANN does not have the ability to censor the Internet
column4: the corporation's CEO Goran Marby said during the hearing.

column1: Tech companies
column2: technical experts
column3: academics
column4: have said the transition is overdue and necessary to keep the Internet open and globally oriented
column5: and that the proposal includes safeguards against any potential abuse by any one country.Delaying the transition to the multistakeholder global community may also weaken U.S. credibility in future international negotiations at the United Nations and elsewhere about Internet standards and security
column6: thus empowering countries like Russia and China
column7: experts have said. (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Alan Crosby)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-romneyvoters-idUSKCN11K1S5	Trump’s fate may rest with former supporters of arch-critic Mitt Romney	"
By James Oliphant
| COLUMBUS
column2: Ohio

column1: COLUMBUS
column2: Ohio Donald Trump's presidential candidacy has triggered anguished soul searching among many college-educated and affluent Republicans who must decide whether to back him
column3: sit out the election
column4: or do the unthinkable: vote for his opponent
column5: Hillary Clinton.With less than two months to go before the Nov. 8 election
column6: rural
column7: white voters who lack a college degree have flocked to Trump. But his brash style and lack of experience in government are a much tougher sell among well-off Republicans who have long been a backbone of the party
column8: according to Reuters/Ipsos polling and interviews with Republican-leaning white collar professionals.Trump's hopes of capturing the White House may rest on whether he can win over enough of these voters in battleground states such as Ohio
column9: Virginia and Colorado to offset Clinton's overwhelming advantages with minority voters
column11: urban voters and women.""If you had told me two years ago that I would be voting for Hillary Clinton
column15: chief operating officer of a Columbus-based apparel firm.Sheehan is now leaning toward Clinton
column17: because he worries Trump would damage U.S. relations abroad.Reuters/Ipsos polling shows that Clinton is doing better among affluent and college-educated voters than President Barack Obama did four years ago
column18: even among Republicans. It's a warning  signal for Trump
column19: who has been shunned by blacks
column21: nearly nine out of every 10 Republicans with a college degree and annual income over $100
column22: 000 supported then Republican candidate Mitt Romney. Now
column23: about seven in 10 support Trump.Romney won college-educated voters over Obama by 4 percentage points in 2012
column24: but the Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll showed Clinton with a 48-28 percent advantage among those same voters last month. The same gap is playing out in key swing states. In Ohio
column25: Clinton has a 47-36 percent edge among the college educated
column26: according to a Monmouth University poll in August. ""It's amazing how few Trump supporters I've run into
column28: a partner in a prominent Columbus law firm who backed Romney in 2012 but who likely will vote for Clinton.

column1: Marsha Blackburn
column2: a congresswoman from Tennessee who is one of Trump's biggest supporters in Washington
column3: said Trump's proposal this week for a child-care tax credit was an example of policies that can appeal to more affluent Republicans. Trump still needs to ""keep pushing his economic message
column4: keep talking about national security
column5: keep talking about these issues that are so important to moms
column6: these working-family issues

column1: Ohio
column2: with its 18 electoral votes
column3: is crucial for Trump and he has campaigned intensively in the state. But in populous
column4: largely suburban central Ohio
column5: Trump has a tougher task than in the rural counties that surround it.

column1: The local economy skews toward white-collar workers and professionals and does not depend on the manufacturing revival Trump has promised in his ""Make America Great Again"" message.Romney
column2: the scion of a wealthy family and former private equity fund manager
column3: was a more natural fit with many Republicans in the area. He epitomized what sometimes has been called the ""country club Republicans."" They favor smaller government
column4: less intrusive regulations and put less weight on conservative social values.Trump
column5: the real-estate magnate from Manhattan
column6: would seem similar
column7: but some Republican professionals in central Ohio can't get past his temperament and comments like the one suggesting illegal immigrants from Mexico are rapists and murderers. Romney himself has been a fierce critic of Trump.""There's no way I could ever vote for that guy
column10: adding that Trump's criticism of the family of a Muslim soldier
column13: soured him on Trump for good.An NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist poll of registered voters last month showed Clinton ahead among white
column15: where she held a 55-23 percent edge; in North Carolina
column16: where she held a 47-40 percent advantage; and in Virginia
column17: where she held a 43-37 percent edge.

column1: Bradley Barbin
column2: a white-collar criminal defense lawyer in Columbus
column3: has decorated the walls of his office with Republican memorabilia stretching back a century. He faults Trump for stirring resentment and for encouraging violence at his rallies.Trump has denied there is significant violence at his events and has blamed the media for exaggerating scuffles with protesters.Barbin said he likely won't back Clinton. ""Do I know exactly what I am going to do? No. But I do know that Trump's the bigger problem
column4: he said.Among affluent Republicans who do support Trump
column5: several said that whatever reservations they may have about him as a candidate
column6: it was more important to keep Clinton from the presidency.""I think she's a bad person
column8: a retired nephrologist who lives in Hilliard
column10: who lauded Trump as an agent of change.Trump's campaign has long contended there exists a swath of Trump voters who won't talk to the press or pollsters for fear of being demonized
column11: but who will show up at the polls in November.But it's also possible that some Republicans
column12: once in the privacy of the voting booth
column13: will go with Clinton because of their concerns about Trump. Barbin
column15: said that's the takeaway from conversations with his peers.""We all know
column17: ""that there are certain people you just cannot give that kind of unfettered power to. You just can't."" (Additional reporting by Chris Kahn and Grant Smith; Editing by Caren Bohan and Ross Colvin)"
